message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has tenderness along the ribs on the right side, suggesting potential thoracic spine injury. A CT scan of the cervical spine is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for any cervical spine injury that could be missed on physical examination. X-rays of the neck or right wrist would not address potential spine injury, and the patient has no abdominal symptoms to warrant a focused assessment with sonography in trauma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient fell off a height and has tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side, suggesting the possibility of cervical spine injury. CT scan of the cervical spine is the most appropriate next step in management to rule out any cervical spine fractures. X-ray of the neck or wrist would not provide enough information about the possible cervical spine injury. Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma is used for assessing abdominal trauma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side, which suggests a possible rib fracture. There is also tenderness and limited mobility in the right wrist, which suggests a possible fracture or sprain. However, the most important concern in a fall from height is cervical spine injury. Therefore, CT scan of the cervical spine is the most appropriate next step in management to rule out any cervical spine injury. X-ray of the neck is not as sensitive as CT scan in detecting cervical spine injury. Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) is used to assess for free fluid in the abdomen and chest, which may indicate internal bleeding. X-ray of the right wrist should also be performed to rule out any fracture or sprain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient fell off a roof, indicating high-risk factors for cervical spine injury. CT scan of the cervical spine is the imaging of choice for patients with suspected cervical spine injury, especially for those with high-risk features. The other options can be considered as needed depending on the clinical situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient fell off a roof and has tenderness along the ribs on the right side, and a cervical collar is already in place. A CT scan of the cervical spine is the most appropriate next step to rule out any spinal injuries. X-ray of the neck or wrist may be helpful, but the risk of spinal injury takes precedence. Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) is used to assess for intra-abdominal injuries and is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient fell from a height and has tenderness along the ribs, which suggests possible rib fractures and concern for spinal injury. A CT scan of the cervical spine is most appropriate for evaluating spinal cord injury. While the other options may be useful in evaluating other injuries, the concern for spinal cord injury takes priority in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient fell off a roof and has tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side, which suggests the possibility of spinal injury. Therefore, a CT scan of the cervical spine is the most appropriate next step in management. X-ray of the neck may not provide enough information on spinal injury, while Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and X-ray of the right wrist are not necessary at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side, suggesting a possible rib fracture. The presence of a cervical collar on arrival may also indicate possible cervical spine injury. For these reasons, a CT scan of the cervical spine would be the most appropriate next step in management to evaluate for any potential injuries. Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma may be useful for assessing any potential intra-abdominal injuries, but it is not the most appropriate next step in this case. X-ray of the neck and the right wrist may be indicated depending on the clinical suspicion, but they are not the most urgent next steps in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the mechanism of injury and the tenderness along the 2nd and 3rd ribs on the right side, there is a possibility of cervical spine injury. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to obtain a CT scan of the cervical spine to rule out any fractures or other injuries. X-ray of the neck or right wrist would not provide adequate evaluation for possible cervical spine injury. Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma would be indicated if there were signs of internal bleeding or abdominal trauma, which is not evident in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple injuries and suspected spinal injury. The most appropriate next step in management would be a CT scan of the cervical spine to evaluate for any spinal injuries. X-ray of the neck is not sufficient to rule out any fractures. Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST) and X-ray of the right wrist are not urgent priorities given the suspected spinal injury.
